required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluating an Online Adjunctive Support Following Intensive Services (OASIS) Strategy for Youth With Selective Mutism
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluating an Online Adjunctive Support Following Intensive Services (OASIS) Strategy for Youth With Selective Mutism

brief_summary.textblock: This study seeks to evaluate an innovative post-acute continuation/transition planning treatment strategy that leverages intensive treatment followed by online, videoconferencing-based "booster" sessions for youth with selective mutism (SM). Twenty children between the ages of 4 and 10 and their caregivers will participate in an intensive group behavioral treatment (IGBT) for SM and will be subsequently randomized to receive either (a) six, biweekly, hour-long, videoconferencing-delivered booster sessions or (b) no additional treatment for 12 weeks. All families will participate in assessments at the following time points: Intake (i.e., 4-5 months prior to the IGBT); Baseline (i.e., 1 month prior to the IGBT), Post-IGBT (i.e., 2 weeks following the IGBT), Biweekly (i.e., between Post-IGBT and School Year Follow-Up), and School Year Follow Up (i.e., 16 weeks following the IGBT).

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participating families will be randomly assigned to either receive the post-acute continuation strategy sessions or no additional treatment for 12 weeks following the IGBT.
study_design_info.masking_description: "Independent evaluators" assigned to assess outcomes at Post-IGBT and School Year Follow-Up time points will be unfamiliar with families' progress during the IGBT, as well as masked to random assignment (i.e., whether or not families participated in the post-acute continuation strategy sessions).

primary_outcome.measure: Clinical Global Impressions - Improvement (CGI-I) Scale rating at Post-IGBT
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 3 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
primary_outcome.description: The CGI-I Scale (Guy & Bonato, 1970) is a widely used global improvement measure; improvement is rated on a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse). Independent evaluators masked to family participation/progress during the intensive group behavioral treatment (IGBT) will complete the CGI-I rating. "Treatment Response" is defined as an independent evaluator rated CGI-I rating of 1 or 2 (ratings >/= 3 represent "Treatment Nonresponse").

primary_outcome.measure: Clinical Global Impressions - Improvement (CGI-I) Scale rating at School Year Follow Up
primary_outcome.time_frame: 16-18 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
primary_outcome.description: The CGI-I Scale (Guy & Bonato, 1970) is a widely used global improvement measure; improvement is rated on a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse). Independent evaluators masked to family participation/progress during the intensive group behavioral treatment (IGBT) and the post-acute strategy will complete the CGI-I rating. "Treatment Response" is defined as an independent evaluator rated CGI-I rating of 1 or 2 (ratings >/= 3 represent "Treatment Nonresponse").

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Anxiety Disorders Interview Schedule for Children (ADIS) Clinical Severity Ratings (CSRs) at Post-IGBT
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 3 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The ADIS (Silverman & Albano, 1996) is a well-supported semi-structured diagnostic interview assessing child mental disorders in accordance with the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (DSM). Disorders are assigned a clinical severity rating (CSR) along a 9-point scale ranging from 0-8 (CSRs >/= 4 indicate diagnostic criteria were met). Independent evaluators masked to family participation/progress during the intensive group behavioral treatment (IGBT) will administer the ADIS and determine CSRs.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Anxiety Disorders Interview Schedule for Children (ADIS) Clinical Severity Ratings (CSRs) at School Year Follow Up
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 16-18 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The ADIS (Silverman & Albano, 1996) is a well-supported semi-structured diagnostic interview assessing child mental disorders in accordance with the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (DSM). Disorders are assigned a clinical severity rating (CSR) along a 9-point scale ranging from 0-8 (CSRs >/= 4 indicate diagnostic criteria were met). Independent evaluators masked to family participation/progress during the intensive group behavioral treatment (IGBT) and post-acute strategy will administer the ADIS and determine CSRs.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Post-IGBT in Anxiety Disorders Interview Schedule for Children (ADIS) Clinical Severity Ratings (CSRs) at School Year Follow Up
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 16-18 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The ADIS (Silverman & Albano, 1996) is a well-supported semi-structured diagnostic interview assessing child mental disorders in accordance with the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (DSM). Disorders are assigned a clinical severity rating (CSR) along a 9-point scale ranging from 0-8 (CSRs >/= 4 indicate diagnostic criteria were met). Independent evaluators masked to family participation/progress during the intensive group behavioral treatment (IGBT) and post-acute strategy will administer the ADIS and determine CSRs.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Children's Global Assessment Scale (CGAS) rating at Post-IGBT
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 3 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The CGAS (Shaffer et al., 1983) is a widely used measure of overall child disturbance, with scores ranging from 0-100. Lower scores indicate greater functional impairment. Independent evaluators masked to family participation/progress during the intensive group behavioral treatment (IGBT) will complete the CGAS rating.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Children's Global Assessment Scale (CGAS) rating at School Year Follow Up
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 16-18 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The CGAS (Shaffer et al., 1983) is a widely used measure of overall child disturbance, with scores ranging from 0-100. Lower scores indicate greater functional impairment. Independent evaluators masked to family participation/progress during the intensive group behavioral treatment (IGBT) and post-acute strategy will complete the CGAS rating.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Post-IGBT in Children's Global Assessment Scale (CGAS) rating at School Year Follow Up
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 16-18 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The CGAS (Shaffer et al., 1983) is a widely used measure of overall child disturbance, with scores ranging from 0-100. Lower scores indicate greater functional impairment. Independent evaluators masked to family participation/progress during the intensive group behavioral treatment (IGBT) and post-acute strategy will complete the CGAS rating.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Selective Mutism Questionnaire (SMQ) scores at Post-IGBT
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 3 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The SMQ (Bergman et al., 2008) is a well-supported parent-report questionnaire with 23 items assessing child verbal behavior across settings (i.e., home, school, community) and associated impairment. Items are rated from 0 (never) to 3 (always).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Selective Mutism Questionnaire (SMQ) scores at School Year Follow Up
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 16-18 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The SMQ (Bergman et al., 2008) is a well-supported parent-report questionnaire with 23 items assessing child verbal behavior across settings (i.e., home, school, community) and associated impairment. Items are rated from 0 (never) to 3 (always).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Post-IGBT in Selective Mutism Questionnaire (SMQ) scores at School Year Follow Up
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 16-18 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The SMQ (Bergman et al., 2008) is a well-supported parent-report questionnaire with 23 items assessing child verbal behavior across settings (i.e., home, school, community) and associated impairment. Items are rated from 0 (never) to 3 (always).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in School Speech Questionnaire (SSQ) scores at School Year Follow Up
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 16-18 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The SSQ (Bergman et al., 2002) is a teacher-report adapted from the SMQ with 6 items assessing child verbal behavior in school. Items are rated from 0 (never) to 3 (always).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Impairment Rating Scale - Parent Version (IRS-P) at School Year Follow Up
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 16-18 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The IRS-P (Fabiano et al., 2006) is a 7-item parent-report measure of child impairment in the home, community, and school settings. Items are rated on a 7-point scale ranging from 0 (no problem) to 6 (extreme problem).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Impairment Rating Scale - Teacher Version (IRS-T) at School Year Follow Up
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 16-18 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The IRS-T (Fabiano et al., 2006) is an 8-item teacher-report measure of child impairment in the school setting. Items are rated on a 7-point scale ranging from 0 (no problem) to 6 (extreme problem).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Selective Mutism Interaction Coding System - Extended/Revised (SMICS-ER) scores at Post-IGBT
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 3 weeks after the Intensive Group Behavioral Treatment (IGBT)
secondary_outcome.description: The SMICS-ER (adapted from Kurtz et al., 2007) is a structured behavioral observation task that assesses child communication behaviors in a naturalistic, laboratory setting across three situations: (1) alone with a caregiver; (2) with a caregiver and novel individual in the room; (3) when asked a question by a novel individual. Child communicative behaviors are coded (e.g., nonverbal, barely audible, verbal) and tallied.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Online Adjunctive Support following Intensive Services (OASIS)
arm_group.description: The OASIS arm consists of additional treatment following participation in the IGBT.
The Control arm consists of no additional treatment following participation in the IGBT.

intervention.description: The IGBT is a 5-day treatment program that delivers cognitive behavioral therapy to children and their caregivers in a group format across 6-8 hours per day.
intervention.arm_group_label: Online Adjunctive Support following Intensive Services (OASIS)

intervention.intervention_name: Online Adjunctive Support following Intensive Services (OASIS) Strategy
intervention.description: The OASIS Strategy includes six, biweekly, hour-long, videoconferencing-based treatment sessions focused on generalizing and maintaining treatment gains across 12 weeks following participation in an intensive group behavioral treatment (IGBT).
intervention.arm_group_label: Online Adjunctive Support following Intensive Services (OASIS)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Child between the ages of 4-10 years, and his or her caregiver(s)
- Child meets DSM-5 criteria for selective mutism diagnosis
- Child speaks English fluently
Exclusion Criteria:
- Child is identified as having any psychiatric condition significantly more impairing than selective mutism that requires alternate treatment
- The child is nonverbal with all caregivers
